intro: Entandrophragma angolense var. septentrionale, commonly known as the African mahogany, is a tropical tree native to Central and Southern Africa. It belongs to the family Rubiaceae and is characterized by its straight, heavy-grained wood that is highly valued for its durability and aesthetic qualities. The tree typically grows to a height of 20–30 meters and has elliptical, dark green leaves that are opposite in arrangement. Its flowers are small and white, often clustered in panicles, and it produces small, round fruits that contain one or two seeds.
